article_title: Climate change seen as big problem in state, poll shows
article_text:
Climate change seen as big problem in state, poll shows

Photo: Damian Dovarganes, Associated Press California Gov. Jerry Brown signs landmark legislation, SB350, in...

As world leaders gather in Paris for an unprecedented discussion on global warming, 57 percent of Californians see climate change as a very serious problem, according to a new poll released by the Public Policy Institute of California.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By John Wildermuth
article_metadata.description: “The numbers aren’t surprising after a decade of both Republican and Democratic governors supporting efforts to fight global warming and California’s long history of environmentalism,” Baldassare said.  Concerns about climate change are even stronger among ethnic Californians, with 63 percent of Latinos, 66 percent of Asians and 71 percent of blacks seeing global warming as a serious problem, compared with 51 percent of the white adults surveyed.  “There’s a sense of vulnerability we’re seeing in the polls (among ethnic residents) when it comes to global warming and climate change,” he added.  Among all adults, 45 percent believe efforts to reduce global warming will increase the number of jobs in the states, compared with 19 percent who say it will boost unemployment.  Not surprisingly, the poll shows a wide partisan divide on the issue of climate change, with California Republicans, mirroring the national GOP leadership, far less concerned about global warming.  A solid 35 percent of GOP voters say global warming is not a problem at all, compared to 4 percent of Democrats and 12 percent of independents.  There’s a similar divide on the jobs question, with 39 percent of Republicans convinced that the state’s fight against global warming will mean fewer jobs for Californians.  More than half the Californians surveyed support Obama’s controversial Affordable Care Act, even though 80 percent of the state’s Republicans have an unfavorable view of it.  When asked to rank possible ballot issues in the November 2016 election, 63 percent of the state’s adults ranked school bonds as very important, 57 percent said increasing the minimum wage was at the top and 36 percent said extending the Proposition 30 tax increases, due to expire in 2018.
